CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: We compared the experimental I SC under the simulated AM1.5 irradiation and the I SC calculated by integrating the EQE and the actual AM1.5 solar spectra. The calculated I SC from the EQE was 15% less than the measured I SC . This discrepancy might be attributed to the spectral mismatch in the NIR region and / or device degradation during measurements in air. The highest PCE of PSCs based on the PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) : PC 70 BM system reached 2.71% , which was lower than the 4-5 % of the P3HT : PCBM devices. This could be mainly attributed to the lower V OC ( ∼ 0.4 V ). In addition , the charge separation efficiency in the current combination might not be as high as that in P3HT : PCBM , although it was difficult to estimate the internal quantum efficiency ( IQE ) accurately due to the light interference effect in the films. This might be attributed to the smaller LUMO offset or less ideal mixing morphology between the polymer and PCBM. Nevertheless , this performance is more than double of the highest PCE ( 1.1% ) reported to date for μmR - polymers , even when the spectral mismatch in the NIR region above was considered. Such improvement of PCE comes from relatively highefficiency photon - to - electron conversion in the broad range of the absorption in the blend film of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PCBM. Considering the high EQE obtained in the range from 650 to 950 nm , PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) is a promising candidate for applications in tandem photovoltaic devices in combination with conventional visible light absorbing materials. Furthermore , comparing the photovoltaic performance of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) with PDTP - DTDPP(EH) suggests that the alkyl chain in the DPP segment has a large influence on the photovoltaic properties of the polymers. A similar phenomenon was also observed for other D-A type photovoltaic polymers. 12 Synthesis of new μmR - polymers with different alkyl chain in both the DTDPP segment and the dithieno[3,2-b : 2^0 ,3 0 -d]pyrrole segment and a detailed comparison of the properties of all these polymers are now in progress. The energy loss from the low output voltage of the photovoltaic devices ( 0.38 - 0.4 V ) can be attributed to the relatively large difference between the LUMO levels of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PCBM ( i.e. , small energy difference between the HOMO of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and LUMO of PCBM ). There is still a room to lower the LUMO level of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) from 3.63 to ∼ 4.0 eV , which is ∼ 0.3 eV higher than the LUMO level of PCBM. If we can control the mixing morphology suitable for the charge separation , this energy offset might be enough to maintain a sufficient driving force for charge transfer and the higher V OC could be expected at the same time.

Let's think step by step.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) |
| P3HT |
| PCBM |
| PDTP-DTDPP(EH) |
| μmR-polymers |
| DPP |
| dithieno[3,2-b:2',3'-d]pyrrole |
| HOMO |
| LUMO |
| PC |

Note:

* PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) and PDTP-DTDPP(EH) are both referred to as "PDTP-DTDPP" in the paragraph, but they are different materials with different alkyl chains in the DPP segment.
* μmR-polymers are a class of polymers, not a specific material.
* HOMO and LUMO are abbreviations for "highest occupied molecular orbital" and "lowest unoccupied molecular orbital", respectively. They are not specific materials, but rather concepts used to describe the electronic properties of molecules.
* PC is an abbreviation for "polycrystalline". It is not a specific material, but rather a term used to describe the crystal structure of some materials.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) |
| P3HT |
| PCBM |
| PDTP-DTDPP(EH) |
| μmR-polymers |

Note:

* The entities "HOMO" and "LUMO" were removed since they are not material names, but rather concepts used to describe electronic properties.
* The entity "PC" was removed since it is not a specific material name, but rather an abbreviation for "polycrystalline".
* The entity "DPP" was removed since it is not a specific material name, but rather an abbreviation for "dithieno[3,2-b:2',3'-d]pyrrole".
* The entity "dithieno[3,2-b:2',3'-d]pyrrole" was removed since it is not a specific material name, but rather a chemical formula for a class of materials.

Let's think step by step.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| I SC |
| EQE |
| PCE |
| V OC |
| LUMO |
| HOMO |
| IQE |

Note:

* I SC stands for "short-circuit current"
* EQE stands for "external quantum efficiency"
* PCE stands for "power conversion efficiency"
* V OC stands for "open-circuit voltage"
* LUMO stands for "lowest unoccupied molecular orbital"
* HOMO stands for "highest occupied molecular orbital"
* IQE stands for "internal quantum efficiency"

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| PCE |
| V OC |
| LUMO |

Note:

* EQE stands for "external quantum efficiency"
* PCE stands for "power conversion efficiency"
* V OC stands for "open-circuit voltage"
* LUMO stands for "lowest unoccupied molecular orbital"

Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: We compared the experimental I SC under the simulated AM1.5 irradiation and the I SC calculated by integrating the EQE and the actual AM1.5 solar spectra. The calculated I SC from the EQE was 15% less than the measured I SC . This discrepancy might be attributed to the spectral mismatch in the NIR region and / or device degradation during measurements in air. The highest PCE of PSCs based on the PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) : PC 70 BM system reached 2.71% , which was lower than the 4-5 % of the P3HT : PCBM devices. In addition , the charge separation efficiency in the current combination might not be as high as that in P3HT : PCBM , although it was difficult to estimate the internal quantum efficiency ( IQE ) accurately due to the light interference effect in the films. This might be attributed to the smaller LUMO offset or less ideal mixing morphology between the polymer and PCBM. Nevertheless , this performance is more than double of the highest PCE ( 1.1% ) reported to date for μmR - polymers , even when the spectral mismatch in the NIR region above was considered. Such improvement of PCE comes from relatively highefficiency photon - to - electron conversion in the broad range of the absorption in the blend film of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PCBM. Considering the high EQE obtained in the range from 650 to 950 nm , PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) is a promising candidate for applications in tandem photovoltaic devices in combination with conventional visible light absorbing materials. A similar phenomenon was also observed for other D-A type photovoltaic polymers. 12 Synthesis of new μmR - polymers with different alkyl chain in both the DTDPP segment and the dithieno[3,2-b : 2^0 ,3 0 -d]pyrrole segment and a detailed comparison of the properties of all these polymers are now in progress. The energy loss from the low output voltage of the photovoltaic devices ( 0.38 - 0.4 V ) can be attributed to the relatively large difference between the LUMO levels of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PCBM ( i.e. , small energy difference between the HOMO of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and LUMO of PCBM ). There is still a room to lower the LUMO level of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) from 3.63 to ∼ 4.0 eV , which is ∼ 0.3 eV higher than the LUMO level of PCBM. If we can control the mixing morphology suitable for the charge separation , this energy offset might be enough to maintain a sufficient driving force for charge transfer and the higher V OC could be expected at the same time.

Let's think step by step.

| Property Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| 15% | Discrepancy between experimental ISC and calculated ISC from EQE and AM1.5 solar spectra |
| 2.71% | Highest PCE of PSCs based on PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) : PC 70 BM system |
| 4-5% | PCE of P3HT : PCBM devices |
| 0.4 V | VOC of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) : PC 70 BM system |
| 1.1% | Highest PCE reported to date for μmR-polymers |
| 650-950 nm | Range of high EQE obtained for PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) |
| 0.38-0.4 V | Energy loss from low output voltage of photovoltaic devices |
| 3.63 eV | LUMO level of PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) |
| 4.0 eV | Desired LUMO level of PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) |
| 0.3 eV | Energy difference between HOMO of PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) and LUMO of PCBM |

Note: The values in the "Description" column are not necessarily numerical values, but rather a brief description of the property or characteristic being referred to.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Value of material property" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| 15% | Discrepancy between experimental ISC and calculated ISC from EQE and AM1.5 solar spectra |
| 2.71% | Highest PCE of PSCs based on PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) : PC 70 BM system |
| 0.4 V | VOC of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) : PC 70 BM system |
| 1.1% | Highest PCE reported to date for μmR-polymers |
| 650-950 nm | Range of high EQE obtained for PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) |
| 0.38-0.4 V | Energy loss from low output voltage of photovoltaic devices |

Note: The entities that were removed were "4-5%" and "0.3 eV" as they do not clearly refer to the value of a material property. The value "4-5%" is a comparison of the PCE of P3HT : PCBM devices and not a specific value of a material property. The value "0.3 eV" is the energy difference between the HOMO of PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) and LUMO of PCBM, which is not a material property.
